The Dance Theatre of Harlem , So Percussion and Sierra Leone's Refugee All Stars are among the dance and music groups slated to perform — for free — Tuesday and Wednesday at the Egg in Albany.
The concerts, set for 7:30 p.m. each night, are part of the New York State Performing Arts Presenter Conference. Admission is open to the public; no reservations are necessary. For additional information, call 473-1845.

Environmental film series opens at Madison Theater 
The 2014 urban-farming documentary "Plant This Movie" will screen at 7:30 p.m. Tuesday at Albany's Madison Theater as part of the Environmental Film Series being planned and presented with the City of Albany and University at Albany Graduate Students for Sustainability .
Written and directed by Karney Hatch and narrated by Darryl Hannah , "Plant This Movie" looks at urban farmers around the country (New York, Los Angeles, New Orleans and Portland, Ore.) and the world (Havana, Shanghai, Calcutta, Lima, Addis Ababa, London).
Tickets are $8. A mixer is set for 7 p.m.
The series, curated by the city's Sustainability Advisory Committee and UAlbany grad students, is a continuation of the environmental series that kicked off in May and continued on Oct. 12 with "Even The Rain."
Several more films unspooling in the coming months:
"Gasland": Nov. 16. Josh Fox's 2010 fracking expose. With local documentary.
"Urbanized": Nov. 24. Gary Hustwit's 2011 documentary on urban design.
"Chasing Ice": Dec. 15. Jeff Orlowski 's 2012 film tracking photographer James Balog 's efforts to document climate change.
"Idle Threat: Man on Emission": Jan. 26. George Pakehnham's film about his crusade to stop engine-idling New Yorkers.
"Connected by Coffee": Feb. 15. Aaron Dennis 's documentary about the brew, the bean and its growers.
"GMO OMG": March 7. Jeremy Seifert 's critical 2013 look at genetically modified organisms and Monsanto.
"The Human Experiment": April 11. Don Hardy Jr. and Dana Nachman 's documentary on household chemicals.
"The True Cost": May 1. Andrew Morgan 's study of the environmental effects of fashion.
All screenings are 7:30 p.m., with mixers at 7 p.m. For more information, see www.themadisontheater.com or call 438-2094.
Musicians of Ma'alwyck offer some spooky tunes 
If you're already tired of "Monster Mash" this Halloween, the Musicians of Ma'alwyck are offering seasonal tunefulness of a different sort.
The chamber music ensemble will open its 2015-2016 season with two spooky programs: "Macabre Music: The Final Installment," a sort of "greatest hits" of earlier eerie concerts, set for 7 p.m. Friday at First Reformed Church at 8 N. Church St. in Schenectady; and "Murder-Mystery Evening," a special dinner-recital-with-death scheduled for 6 p.m. Saturday at Taste of Europe restaurant at 3630 Route 145 in Cobleskill.
The "Macabre Music" concert will include Saint-Saens' "Danse Macabre," a world premiere by Peter Fitzgerald and other works. Admission is $25, or $10 for students. 
In addition, a free preview of the program will be held from 11:20 a.m. to 12:10 p.m. Wednesday in Carl Taylor Auditorium of Schenectady County Community College .
The "Murder-Mystery Evening" will involve a meal from Chef Jeannette Balins and, according to the group, a violent felony "at a dinner party featuring a performance by an ensemble of misfits and maniacs." Admission is $100 and is limited to 40 people. Call 377-3623
